Reactivity

Basic Reactivity

Reactive elements

Consider this Shiny app:

library(tidyverse)
library(shiny)

data = tidyr::billboard %>%
gather(key = "week", value = "position", starts_with("wk")) %>%
mutate(week = as.numeric(gsub("wk", "", week)))

ui = fluidPage(
titlePanel("Billboard song ranking"),
selectInput("song_selector", "Select a Song:", choices = unique(data$track)),
# Plot output
plotOutput("position_plot")
)
server = function(input, output) {
# Render the plot
output$position_plot <- renderPlot({
# Filter data based on user selection
selected_song_data <- reactive({
filter(data, track == input$song_selector)
})
ggplot(selected_song_data(), aes(x = week, y = position)) +
geom_line() +
labs(title = paste("Position of", input$song_selector, "over Weeks"),
x = "Week",
y = "Position") +
scale_y_reverse(limits = c(100, 0))
})
}

# Create Shiny app ----
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

The reactive elements in this app are outlined in the UI elements in the script:

  • selectInput("song_selector", "Select a Song:", choices = unique(data$track))
  • plotOutput("position_plot")

INSERT PIC HERE

The logic behind those elements are defined in the server:

# Render the plot
output$position_plot <- renderPlot({

# Filter data based on user selection
selected_song_data <- reactive({
filter(data, track == input$song_selector)
})

ggplot(selected_song_data(), aes(x = week, y = position)) +
geom_line() +
labs(title = paste("Position of", input$song_selector, "over Weeks"),
x = "Week",
y = "Position") +
scale_y_reverse(limits = c(100, 0))
})
}

INSERT PIC HERE

Adding in another input:

UI:

sliderInput("week_no", "Week", min = 0 , max = 52, value = c(0,52)),

Server:

selected_song_data <- reactive({
filter(data, track == input$song_selector &
week >= input$week_no[1] &
week <= input$week_no[2])
})

library(tidyverse)
library(shiny)

data = tidyr::billboard %>%
gather(key = "week", value = "position", starts_with("wk")) %>%
mutate(week = as.numeric(gsub("wk", "", week)),
month_entered = strftime(date.entered, "%B"))

ui = fluidPage(
titlePanel("Billboard song ranking"),
selectInput("song_selector", "Select a Song:", choices = unique(data$track)),
sliderInput("week_no", "Week", min = 0 , max = 52, value = c(0,52)),
# Plot output
plotOutput("position_plot")
)
server = function(input, output) {
# Render the plot
output$position_plot <- renderPlot({
# Filter data based on user selection
selected_song_data <- reactive({
filter(data, track == input$song_selector &
week >= input$week_no[1] &
week <= input$week_no[2])
})
ggplot(selected_song_data(), aes(x = week, y = position)) +
geom_line() +
labs(title = paste("Position of", input$song_selector, "over Weeks"),
x = "Week",
y = "Position") +
scale_y_reverse(limits = c(100, 0))
})
}

# Create Shiny app ----
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

Question:

What does our reactive graph look like now?

Exercise 1:

Using the code below, add a table that displays the week by week position of the song. Use renderTable() and tableOutput(). Make sure that the slider does not have any effect on the table. What does this react graph now look like?

library(tidyverse)
library(shiny)

data = tidyr::billboard %>%
gather(key = "week", value = "position", starts_with("wk")) %>%
mutate(week = as.numeric(gsub("wk", "", week)),
month_entered = strftime(date.entered, "%B"))

ui = fluidPage(
titlePanel("Billboard song ranking"),
selectInput("song_selector", "Select a Song:", choices = unique(data$track)),
sliderInput("week_no", "Week", min = 0 , max = 52, value = c(0,52)),
# Plot output
plotOutput("position_plot")
)
server = function(input, output) {
# Render the plot
output$position_plot <- renderPlot({
# Filter data based on user selection
selected_song_data <- reactive({
filter(data, track == input$song_selector &
week >= input$week_no[1] &
week <= input$week_no[2])
})
ggplot(selected_song_data(), aes(x = week, y = position)) +
geom_line() +
labs(title = paste("Position of", input$song_selector, "over Weeks"),
x = "Week",
y = "Position") +
scale_y_reverse(limits = c(100, 0))

Using a reactive value

These are an example of a ‚Äúreactive conductor‚Äù as they exist in between sources (e.g. an input) and endpoints (e.g. an output).

As such a reactive() depends on various upstream inputs and can be used to generate output.

Their primary use is similar to a function in an R script, they help to

  • avoid repeating yourself

  • decompose complex computations into smaller / more modular steps

  • can improve computational efficiency by breaking up / simplifying reactive dependencies

reactive() tips

  • Code written similarly to render*() functions

  • If react_obj = reactive({...}) then any consumer must access value using react_obj() and not react_obj

    • think of react_obj as a function that returns the current value

    • Common cause of everyone‚Äôs my favorite R error ,

      ## Error: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable`

  • Like input reactive expressions may only be used within a reactive context (e.g. render*(), reactive(), observer(), etc.)

    ## Error: Operation not allowed without an active reactive context. (You tried to do something that can only be done from inside a reactive expression or observer.)
